data.title: Jerry Lee Lewis: Trouble in Mind (2022)
data.meta_description: An electrifying glimpse into the complex life and thrilling, unparalleled performances of rock and roll's first and wildest practitioner: Jerry Lee Lewis.
data.text:
Jerry Lee was the ne plus ultra of terrifying redneck speed freaks lost in the transcendent sin of rock & roll. Nobody could remotely do what he could do, and he invented a genre that contains only him, yet remains rock ‘n’ roll in its absolutely purest form.

This is the polar opposite of that unbelievable piece of shit Little Richard film. Directed by Ethan Coen and edited by his wife, Tricia Cooke, there’s not one word of narration or voiceover that doesn’t belong to Jerry Lee.

They contextualize Jerry Lee’s impenetrable - and clearly psychopathic - genius through the various incredibly stupid condescending clueless assholes who hosted him on their television shows over the decades.

Jerry Lee’s essence is his…

It would not seem to me that Ethan Coen and Tricia Cooke, of all people, would have any need for an editing exercise at this stage in their careers, but I can't really explain what this is in any other way. Take a bunch of publicly available footage, put some limits on what you're going to permit yourself to use, see if you can get a satisfying movie out of it. The answer is pretty unambiguously "no", and as dull as I found the the whole thing, the point at the end where the movie throws up its hands in defeat and provides title cards to explain very basic biographical facts that we probably needed right at the start moved…

After weeks of quipping that I would celebrate the 4th of July by leaving the United States, I opted to watch this tribute to a Real American Hero while our flight escaped the national airspace. Although Ethan Coen is the credited director, the documentary's lively all-clips structure suggests equal if not greater authorship from editor Tricia Cooke, also Coen's life partner and co-creator of Drive-Away Dolls.

There's some loose biography in here, nuggets of Jerry Lee Lewis' life slipping out through interview clips and archival images, enough to get some sense of his progression from child piano prodigy to iconic rock n' roll madman, scandal sheet regular and slightly chastened country/gospel elder. In its selected representation, Trouble in Mind brings…
